block.p: Direct flights from Moscow to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews will not be permitted by the Soviet Union, which, under pressure from Arab nations, rejected an appeal by the Bush Administration.
Direct flights from Moscow to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews will not be permitted by the Soviet Union, which, under pressure from Arab nations, rejected an appeal by the Bush Administration.
Direct flights from Moscow to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews will not be permitted by the Soviet Union, which, under pressure from Arab nations, rejected an appeal by the Bush Administration.
B'nai B'rith International reopens a chapter in Budapest

Prime Minister Hans Modrow criticized Bonn for not providing immediate financial assitance to East Germany. Bonn has said it will extend aid only to the government that emerges after free elections in March.
The reunification of Germany is opposed by roughly two out of three Poles, but a majority of Russians and Hungarians favor the idea, according to a poll of political views in eight European nations.

News analysis: Ion Iliescu, Romania's provisional President, is struggling to form a new government while haunted by the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu. He vowed to punish new demonstrations like the one on Sunday.
Eastern Europe's brainpower promises to be a powerful resource for American companies, which so far have only seen the newly open nations as potential markets.
The experiment that is Hungary's stock exchange

Sweden's social welfare system may not survive the maneuvering by the leaders of the nation's poltical parties, which are trying to form a new government after the Social Democratic Government resigned last week.

News analysis: Japan's election raises the question: Will the victory by the Liberal Democratic Party help resolve the trade and security disputes tearing at relations between Japan and the United States?
Prime Minister Kaifu of Japan, bolstered by a sweeping election victory on Sunday, consolidated his power within the Liberal Democratic Party to guarantee his position for 18 more months.
China warns against ethnic independence movements
China ends silence on deal that was rescinded by the U.S.
Demonstrators battle police as Cheney arrives in Manila

A democracy movement in Nepal was born in a hail of broken bricks and stones during demonstrations in Katmandu over the weekend. Troops and riot policemen are swarming the streets as a general strike takes effect.
Nicaraguan opposition coalition split by ideology and rivalries
Whither goes the stream of U.S. dollars?
Doctor-patient relationships have become a distorted version of the rosy image most Americans have. Patients and doctors now say distrust and leeriness have replaced caring and communication.
American Medical Association is splintered by challenges

Cuban-Americans await Castro's fall with renewed hope in light of events in Eastern Europe, even though experts say there is little sign that the Cuban leader is in imminent danger of being overthrown.
Racial tensions in Selma simmer just beneath the surface of amiable social interaction. ''We're still two separate and paranoid communities,'' a minister said.
The Boston School Committee has been accused by the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter of acting in a racist manner in ousting the city's first black School Superintendent last week.

A prisoner's right to have children will be considered by the United States Court of Appeals in St. Louis. A Missouri prisoner wants to sire a child by artificial insemination, but prison officials have refused.
Beefed-up enforcement at the I.R.S. is not likely to raise $3 billion next year, as President Bush proposes, Congressional tax writers say.
Plan for downpayments on veterans' loans is criticized
Pittston coal miners vote on contract to settle strike
Man posing as wealthy Rothschild heir awaits extradition
The nation's largest airlines, which are gambling on a turnaround after a slowdown in traffic in recent months, could find themselves stretched to remain profitable if current conditions continue.
Seven fall into icy lake in Sierra Nevada; all feared dead
California Journal: A study of feelings creates bad ones
Property taxes in New York City on co-ops and condominiums are increasing dramatically - 15 percent in 1991, 20 percent in 1990 - just as property values are falling.
How to fight a tax assessment

Mayor Dinkins's cultivated cool has helped him make inroads on several fronts seven weeks into his term, but he is now confronted by more intractable challenges as he tries to shape his administration.
Jim Florio's first month as Governor of New Jersey has been devoted to drawing into his office greater personal control of the sprawling bureaucracy of state government.
The Shoreham nuclear power plant, hailed in the 1970's as the answer to the power needs of Long Island but never opened, has become a fading memory for its neighbors.
The new Roman Catholic Bishop for the diocese of Brooklyn, the nation's fifth largest, will be Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Palm Beach, Fla., a church official said.

A security guard arrested in a rape at Columbia University worked for months despite a police record, underscoring, officials say, the questionable hiring practices by some private security companies.
Suspect sought in series of rapes in Brooklyn and Queens
5,000 officers mourn Suffolk detective slain by car bomb
Renewed interest in Malcolm X, 25 years after he was assassinated, has brought a new generation of young people in touch with his works.
Researchers suspect brain impairment in bypass surgery
A new class of optic materials makes light do tricks
Acid rain said to cause damage but not disaster
Did anthropologists 'invent' the culture the Maoris espouse?
Alarming case of disappearing amphibians puzzles scientists
Soviet astronauts return after long mission
Daniel Barenboim on Bach, the Bastille and the baton
Word and Image: A new Anita Brookner novel
Mixed-race children of World War II
Baseball: Salary arbitration still an issue
Boxing: King still factor in Douglas-Holyfield match
Columns: Anderson on fighting in the N.B.A.
Hockey: Rangers beat Devils in overtime
William Reed Huntington, worked for Quakers at the U.N.
Anthony Lewis: But we close our eyes
Flora Lewis: On or off the world?
Peter S. Rashish: A club for East Europe to join
